sub_subject.name: Church History
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Church History (Bible & Theology)

objectives.objective_text: Identify a heresy as a lie about God.
Name the truth: Jesus is God and Man.
Identify that early Christians were hurt for loving Jesus.
Name the Catacombs as places where they hid and prayed.
Identify monks as men who lived alone to pray.
Name Anthony as a man who went to the desert.
Identify an Apologist as someone who explains why Jesus is true.
Name Justin Martyr as a wise teacher.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Identify the Apostolic Fathers as men who knew the disciples.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Name Polycarp as a brave old man who loved Jesus.
Identify a Council as a big meeting of church leaders.
Name the Creed as a statement of what we believe.
Identify John Calvin as a teacher in Geneva.
Name his big book 'The Institutes'.
Identify Martin Luther as a monk with a hammer.
Name the 95 Theses on the door.
Identify the 'Solas' as the 5 Alone's.
Name Grace Alone, Faith Alone, Christ Alone.
Identify Zwingli as a leader in Switzerland.
Name the Anabaptists as people who wanted to be baptized again.
Recall that we must be careful what we listen to.
Observe that the Bible helps us spot lies.
Recall that Jesus said the world would hate His friends.
Observe that the church grew even when it was hard.
Recall that they wanted to be close to God.
Observe that they gave up their money and houses.
Recall that people told lies about Christians.
Observe that we can use words to defend Jesus.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Recall that they wrote letters to encourage churches.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Observe that the church continued after the Bible was finished.
Recall that they agreed Jesus is fully God.
Identify John Wycliffe as the 'Morning Star'.
Name Jan Hus as a brave preacher.
Identify that people started schools to study God.
Name Thomas Aquinas as a smart thinker.
Identify that the big church split in two.
Name the West (Catholic) and the East (Orthodox).
Identify the Pope as the leader of the church in Rome.
Name Rome as the main city.
Recall that he taught us about God's great power.
Observe that Geneva became a city of Bible study.
Recall that Luther said we are saved by faith, not money.
Observe that Luther translated the Bible for everyone.
Recall that Scripture Alone is our rule.
Observe that all is for God's Glory Alone.
Recall that they wanted to obey the Bible exactly.
Observe that they were persecuted by everyone.
Recite a simple line from the Apostles' Creed.
Summarize the error of Gnosticism (Body is bad, Spirit is good).
Explain why Arianism (Jesus is a creature) is wrong.
Explain Docetism (Jesus only *seemed* human).
Defend the biblical view of sin against Pelagius.
Summarize the persecution under Nero (fire in Rome).
Explain why Romans thought Christians were 'haters of mankind'.
Explain the Decian and Diocletian persecutions.
Defend the witness of the martyrs as an apologetic for the truth.
Produce a reflection on the cost of discipleship then and now.
Summarize the life of St. Anthony of Egypt.
Explain why people went to the desert (to escape a worldly church).
Explain the difference between Eremitic (hermit) and Cenobitic (community) monks.
Defend the biblical call to be 'in the world but not of it'.
Produce a reflection on the disciplines of solitude and simplicity.
Summarize the lies told about Christians (cannibalism, atheism).
Explain how Justin Martyr defended the faith to the Emperor.
Explain Irenaeus' fight against Gnosticism.
Defend the rationality of the Christian worldview as presented by the Fathers.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the story of Polycarp's martyrdom.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Explain who Clement of Rome and Ignatius were.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Explain the transition from oral tradition to written record.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Defend the historical continuity of the church.
Summarize the Council of Nicea (325 AD).
Explain why it is important that Jesus is 'of one substance' with the Father.
Memorize the Apostles' Creed.
Explain the term 'Homoousios'.
Defend the orthodoxy of the Nicene Creed against modern heresies.
Produce a study on Athanasius 'Contra Mundum' (Against the World).
Recall that they wanted the Bible in their own language.
Observe that they were treated badly for speaking truth.
Recall that we should love God with our minds.
Observe old universities like Oxford and Paris.
Recall that families sometimes fight.
Observe that they disagreed on rules and leaders.
Recall that Peter and Paul died in Rome.
Observe that the church became very powerful.
Summarize Calvin's emphasis on the glory of God.
Explain what a 'Reformed' church is.
Categorize Geneva as a refuge for Protestants.
Explain the sovereignty of God in salvation.
Defend the doctrine of Predestination as biblical.
Summarize the story of the lightning storm and Luther's vow.
Explain what an 'Indulgence' was (paying for forgiveness).
Explain the concept of the 'Priesthood of all Believers'.
Defend the necessity of the breach with Rome.
Summarize the meaning of each Sola.
Explain why 'Alone' is the most important word.
Explain the sufficiency of Christ (Solus Christus).
Defend 'Sola Fide' as the article on which the church stands or falls.
Produce an essay on the interconnectedness of the five doctrines.
Summarize Zwingli's disagreement with Luther (Marburg Colloquy).
Explain why Anabaptists believed in believer's baptism.
Explain the tragedy of Protestants persecuting Protestants.
Defend the concept of a 'Believers' Church'.
Produce a study on the Munster Rebellion vs. peaceful Anabaptists.
Compare truth with a counterfeit (looks real but isn't).
Apply the need to know the real Jesus.
Analyze the danger of Marcionism (rejecting the Old Testament).
Interpret the error of Pelagianism (we can save ourselves).
Connect ancient heresies to modern cults (e.g., Arianism -> Jehovah's Witnesses).
Compare the safety we have today with the danger back then.
Apply the courage of Perpetua and Felicity.
Analyze the saying 'The blood of the martyrs is the seed of the church'.
Interpret the political reasons for persecution (refusing to say 'Caesar is Lord').
Connect the suffering of the church to the suffering of Christ.
Compare living in the world vs. living in a monastery.
Apply the value of silence and prayer.
Analyze the benefits (preservation of scripture) and dangers (isolation) of monasticism.
Interpret the Benedictine Rule (Ora et Labora - Pray and Work).
Connect monasticism to the preservation of literacy in the Dark Ages.
Compare fighting with swords vs. fighting with truth.
Apply the need to know *why* we believe.
Analyze the dialogue with Trypho the Jew.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Compare the writings of the Apostles (Bible) with the Fathers (Helpful but not inspired).

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Apply the lesson of standing firm in faith from Ignatius.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the 'Didache' as an early church manual.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the letters of Ignatius regarding the role of the bishop.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Connect the Apostolic Fathers to the preservation of the New Testament text.
Compare a Creed with a Hymn.
Analyze the debate between Arius (Jesus is created) and Athanasius (Jesus is God).
Interpret the Nicene Creed's clauses on the Holy Spirit.
Connect the Council of Chalcedon to the doctrine of the Hypostatic Union.
Summarize the life of John Wycliffe.
Explain why the church didn't want people reading the Bible.
Explain the concept of 'Sola Scriptura' before the Reformation.
Defend the right of the laity to read Scripture.
Produce an essay on the cost of reforming the church.
Summarize Anselm's motto: 'Faith seeking understanding'.
Explain what a University is.
Explain the rediscovery of Aristotle.
Defend the substitutionary atonement articulated by Anselm.
Summarize the Great Schism of 1054.
Explain the difference between the Pope (West) and Patriarch (East).
Locate Rome and Constantinople on a map.
Explain the excommunications of 1054.
Defend the importance of unity in truth.
Produce a study on the Fourth Crusade's sack of Constantinople.
Summarize how the Bishop of Rome became the Pope.
Explain the story of Leo the Great stopping Attila the Hun.
Categorize the hierarchy: Pope, Cardinal, Bishop, Priest.
Explain the Donation of Constantine (and its forgery).
Defend the Protestant rejection of the Papacy.
Compare Luther (the starter) with Calvin (the organizer).
Analyze the impact of Calvin's 'Institutes of the Christian Religion'.
Interpret Calvin's view of the Lord's Supper (Spiritual Presence).
Connect Knox, the Puritans, and Pilgrims to Calvin's influence.
Compare Luther's view of salvation with the Pope's view.
Apply the courage of 'Here I Stand'.
Analyze Luther's discovery in Romans 1:17.
Interpret the Diet of Worms.
Connect the printing press to the spread of Luther's ideas.
Compare adding to Jesus vs. Jesus Alone.
Apply 'Soli Deo Gloria' to school and play.
Analyze how each Sola countered a Catholic error.
Interpret Ephesians 2:8-9 in light of the Solas.
Connect Sola Scriptura to authority.
Compare the Magisterial Reformers (church/state) with Radicals (separate).
Apply the courage to stand for conviction.
Analyze the 'Affair of the Sausages' (Zwingli breaking fast).
Interpret the Anabaptist view of the separation of church and state.
Connect the Amish and Mennonites to this movement.
Evaluate the church's response to heresy (it sharpened doctrine).
Evaluate the legal status of Christianity (Religio Illicita) in the Roman Empire.
Evaluate the impact of monasticism on Western civilization.
Evaluate the necessity of precise theological language.
Compare Wycliffe's 'Poor Priests' with rich bishops.
Apply the courage of Jan Hus at the stake.
Interpret the Council of Constance (burning of Hus).
Connect these men to the later work of Martin Luther.
Compare learning in a monastery vs. learning in a university.
Apply the use of logic to faith.
Interpret Anselm's 'Cur Deus Homo' (Why God became Man).
Connect Aquinas' 'Summa Theologica' to Catholic doctrine.
Compare the Latin church with the Greek church.
Analyze the theological causes (Filioque clause).
Interpret the political and cultural divide (Latin vs. Greek).
Connect the Crusades to the deepening of the split.
Compare the authority of the Bible with the authority of the Pope.
Analyze the claim of 'Petrine Supremacy' (Matthew 16).
Interpret Gregory the Great's influence on the medieval church.
Connect the fall of the Roman Empire to the rise of Church power.
Evaluate the affair of Michael Servetus.
Evaluate Luther's later writings and errors.
Evaluate modern evangelicalism through the lens of the Solas.
Evaluate the pacifism of the Radical Reformation.
Construct a taxonomy of Christological heresies.
Synthesize the importance of 'Orthodoxy' (Right Glory/Belief).
Construct a critique of the two-tiered spirituality (monks vs. laity).
Construct a summary of the key arguments in the 'Apology' of Justin.
Synthesize the development of the Rule of Faith.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Construct a timeline of the 1st and 2nd century church leaders.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the apologetic arguments used by early writers against paganism.
Construct a historical overview of the first four Ecumenical Councils.
Evaluate the Lollard movement in England.
Evaluate the 'Filioque' controversy regarding the Trinity.
Evaluate the conflict between Popes and Kings (Investiture Controversy).
Construct a profile of Calvin as a pastor and theologian.
Synthesize the legacy of Calvinism in Western history.
Synthesize the impact of the German Bible.
Construct a systematic defense of the Five Solas.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Apostolic Fathers and Their Writings
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the theology of Clement regarding justification.
Analyze the goal of Scholasticism (systematizing theology).
Interpret the use of Greek philosophy (Logos) to explain Christ.
Analyze Wycliffe's translation of the Bible into English.
Construct a timeline of dissent leading to 1517.
Construct a summary of the Five Ways (Aquinas' arguments for God).
Synthesize the intellectual achievements of the High Middle Ages.
Construct a historical evaluation of the accumulation of Papal power.
Synthesize the mixing of temporal and spiritual power.
Construct a theology of martyrdom.
Construct a theology of the Cross vs. theology of Glory.
Construct a comparison of Lutheran, Reformed, and Anabaptist theology.
Evaluate the risks and rewards of using secular philosophy to explain faith.
Connect the early apologists to modern apologetics.
Construct a comparison of Orthodox and Catholic theology.
Evaluate the synthesis of Greek Philosophy and Biblical Theology.
